list.title: Question 1
list.content: Which is characteristic of both prokaryotes and viruses?I.Contain genetic codeII.Rely on host cell for metabolismIII.Surrounded by cell wallA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and IIC.\hspace{1em}II and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because both prokaryotes and viruses contain a genetic code. Only viruses rely on a host cell for metabolism, and only prokaryotes have a cell wall (Choice B, Choice C, andChoice D).

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Viruses, compared to living organisms, are very small. Which other characteristic listed below distinguishes viruses from unicellular living organisms?A.\hspace{1em}Contain genetic materialB.\hspace{1em}Contain cytoplasmC.\hspace{1em}Lack enzymesD.\hspace{1em}Genetic material is surrounded by a capsid
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because The structure of all viruses includes the presence of a capsid, which surrounds the genetic material (Choice D). Both viruses and living organisms contain genetic material (Choice A). Unicellular living organisms contain cytoplasm (Choice B).  Some viruses lack enzymes, but not all viruses lack enzymes (Choice C).

list.title: Question 3
list.content: Bacteriophages and coronaviruses are both viruses that affect living organisms. Which structures are present in both bacteriophages and coronaviruses?I.cytoplasmII.capsidIII.genetic materialA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because bacteriophages and coronavirus have a capsid and genetic material, and do not have cytoplasm (Choice A, Choice B, andChoice D).

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Which of the rows below shows the correct characteristics of viruses, prokaryotes and eukaryotes?VirusProkaryoteEukaryoteA.\hspace{1em}Genome is DNA or RNAGenome is DNA onlyGenome is DNA onlyB.\hspace{1em}Rely on host cell for nutritionRely on host cell for nutritionDoes not rely on host cell for nutritionC.\hspace{1em}Synthesises ATP for energy supplySynthesises ATP for energy supplySynthesises ATP for energy supplyD.\hspace{1em}Capsid presentCapsid presentCapsid present
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because viruses contain DNA or RNA as their genome. Viruses rely on host cells for nutrition, but prokaryotes and eukaryotes do not (Choice B). Prokaryotes and eukaryotes synthesise ATP, but viruses do not (Choice C). Capsids are present in viruses but not in prokaryotes or eukaryotes (Choice D).

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Viruses have specific components that allow them to infect host cells and replicate. However, some components are not found in both bacteriophages and coronaviruses. Which of the following is not present in BOTH types of viruses?A.\hspace{1em}Genetic information surrounded by a capsidB.\hspace{1em}RNA genomeC.\hspace{1em}Enzymes for replicationD.\hspace{1em}Structures for attachment to a host cell
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because lambda bacteriophages and coronavirus do not have enzymes for replication. The lambda bacteriophage relies entirely on the host cell's machinery for replication and
coronaviruses encode their replication enzyme but do not carry it in the virion.Choice Ais incorrect because both have a capsid containing genetic information.Choice Bis incorrect because although the lambda bacteriophage has a DNA genome, not an RNA genome, coronaviruses do have an RNA genome.Choice Dis incorrect because both of these types of viruses have structures for attachment to the host cells.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Some bacteriophages infect host bacteria using the lytic cycle or the lysogenic cycle.
Which process is characteristic of the lysogenic cycle but not the lytic cycle?A.\hspace{1em}Phage DNA is injected into the host cell.B.\hspace{1em}The phage inserts DNA into host DNA, forming a prophage.C.\hspace{1em}Host bacterium is killed by cell lysis.D.\hspace{1em}Phage proteins bind to receptors on the host bacterium cell.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because phage DNA is inserted into the host cell DNA in the lysogenic cycle, but not the lytic cycle. During the lysogenic cycle and lytic cycle, phage proteins bind to specific receptors on the surface of the host bacterium (Choice D). Phage DNA is then inserted into the host bacterium (Choice A) in both the lysogenic cycle and lytic cycle.  Host bacterial cells are killed by lysis in the lytic cycle (Choice C).

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Which is not a factor in the rapid evolution of the human immunodeficiency virus?A.\hspace{1em}Genetic recombinationB.\hspace{1em}High mutation rateC.\hspace{1em}Slow replication rateD.\hspace{1em}Genetic diversity of host population
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because a slow replication rate is not a factor in the rapid evolution of HIV. Genetic recombination occurs when many strains of the virus infect the same host, and a new combination of genetic material is observed, which leads to changes in the virus (evolution) over time (Choice A).   Mutations occur rapidly in HIV because it is a single-stranded RNA virus and lacks a mechanism to proofread the genome. The introduction of this variation leads to evolution (Choice B). The genome of humans and the HIV host population, has high genetic diversity. Such diversity in the genome may provide a selective advantage for some HIV strains (Choice D).

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Which gives the best summary of the action of reverse transcriptase?A.\hspace{1em}viral DNA→\rarr→viral RNAB.\hspace{1em}viral RNA→\rarr→viral DNAC.\hspace{1em}viral RNA→\rarr→host cell RNAD.\hspace{1em}viral RNA→\rarr→host cell DNA
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because reverse transcriptase is an enzyme used by retroviruses (e.g. HIV) to convert their RNA genome into a DNA copy. This DNA copy is then integrated into the host cell’s genome, allowing the virus to hijack the host's transcription and translation machinery to produce viral proteins and replicate itself.Choice Ais incorrect because a DNA-containing virus would simply use the host cell’s replication mechanisms to replicate its DNA; there would be no need for reverse transcription.Choice Cis incorrect because reverse transcription involves the conversion of RNA into DNA.Choice Dis incorrect because, whilst the viral DNA copy does get incorporated into the host cell’s genome, this cannot be regarded as host cell DNA as it remains distinct from the host's original DNA. It is not accurate to refer to this DNA as "host cell DNA" since it originates from the virus.

list.title: Question 10
list.content: The origin of viruses is an area of active research and exploration. Which statement is not evidence that viruses have origins in other organisms?A.\hspace{1em}Similarities between genome sequence in viral and cellular genes.B.\hspace{1em}Coevolution of viruses and host.C.\hspace{1em}Retroviral enzymes such as reverse transcriptase convert RNA to DNA.D.\hspace{1em}Rate of mutation is rapid in viruses.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because the rapid mutation rate is not evidence of viral origins, but rather a characteristic of some viruses.   Similarities between genome sequences in viral and cellular genes (Choice A), the coevolution of viruses and hosts (Choice B), and retroviral enzymes converting RNA to DNA (Choice C),  are all evidence of viral origins from other organisms.

list.title: Question 14
list.content: Which isnotcharacteristic of HIV?A.\hspace{1em}The viral RNA encodes for reverse transcriptaseB.\hspace{1em}Spike glycoproteins allow for entry into CD4 cellsC.\hspace{1em}Two single strands of RNA are encased in a capsidD.\hspace{1em}Integrase proteins are required for entry into a host cell
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because integrase proteins are not required to enter the host cell; integrase proteins are needed to integrate viral genetic information into host DNA. All other answer options (Choice A, Choice B, andChoice C) are characteristics of HIV.
